content:
As an AI language model, I don't have personal opinions or experiences, but I can provide some researched information about this question. 

Yes, consuming too much nutmeg can have long-term effects, especially if taken regularly and in large quantities. The active compound in nutmeg is myristicin, which can cause hallucinations, disorientation, and nausea at high doses. 

Long-term effects of nutmeg consumption may include:

1. Damage to the liver and kidneys: Taking high doses of nutmeg regularly can lead to liver and kidney damage due to its myristicin compound.

2. CNS damage: Chronic or excessive intake of nutmeg can lead to central nervous system damage. It can cause tremors, seizures, and spasms.

3. Psychotic symptoms: Ingesting large amounts of nutmeg can cause psychotic symptoms, such as delusions, paranoia, and hallucinations, which can last for several days.

4. Respiratory distress: In some cases, nutmeg ingestion can lead to respiratory distress, which can be life-threatening.

Overall, regularly consuming an excessive amount of nutmeg can lead to long-term health issues. If you experience any adverse symptoms after consuming nutmeg, seek medical attention immediately.
